title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
##Assignment

# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dagitty)

#> Warning: Paket 'dagitty' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt

# Load the data
data <- readRDS("C:\\Users\\Deniz\\Documents\\GitHub\\Causal_Data_Science_Data\\customer_sat.rds")

# Explore the data
head(data)



  


summary(data)

#>    follow_ups      satisfaction   subscription      
#>  Min.   : 0.000   Min.   :40.00   Length:15         
#>  1st Qu.: 2.500   1st Qu.:48.50   Class :character  
#>  Median : 7.000   Median :60.00   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   : 5.667   Mean   :60.13                     
#>  3rd Qu.: 8.000   3rd Qu.:72.00                     
#>  Max.   :10.000   Max.   :80.00

# Regression without accounting for subscription
model1 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
summary(model1)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

# Regression accounting for subscription
model2 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = data)
summary(model2)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08


Model 1:
Intercept = 78.9
Follow-up coefficient = -3.3
Model 2:
Intercept = 26.8
Follow-up coefficient = 2.2 Subscription Premium coefficient = 44.7 Subscription Premium+ coefficient = 18.1
In the model without accounting for subscription (model1), the negative coefficient for follow-up calls suggests that more follow-up calls are associated with lower satisfaction. However, this might be confounded by the type of subscription.
In the model accounting for subscription (model2), the positive coefficient for follow-up calls suggests that, after accounting for subscription type, more follow-up calls are associated with higher satisfaction.
The positive coefficients for the “Premium” and “Premium+” subscription levels suggest that clients with these subscriptions tend to report higher satisfaction compared to the reference level.

# Plot the data
ggplot(data, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction, color = subscription)) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Relationship Between Follow-up Calls and Satisfaction",
       x = "Number of Follow-up Calls",
       y = "Satisfaction") +
  theme_minimal()

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
#Assingment Chapter 3
##Dimensions of dataframe

df <- readRDS("data/car_prices.rds")
dim(df)

#> [1] 181  22

View(df)

The dimensions are 181 x 22
##Data types of Dataframe

summary(df)

#>   aspiration         doornumber          carbody           drivewheel       
#>  Length:181         Length:181         Length:181         Length:181        
#>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>  enginelocation       wheelbase        carlength        carwidth    
#>  Length:181         Min.   : 86.60   Min.   :141.1   Min.   :60.30  
#>  Class :character   1st Qu.: 94.50   1st Qu.:166.3   1st Qu.:64.00  
#>  Mode  :character   Median : 96.50   Median :173.0   Median :65.40  
#>                     Mean   : 98.21   Mean   :173.3   Mean   :65.74  
#>                     3rd Qu.:100.40   3rd Qu.:180.2   3rd Qu.:66.50  
#>                     Max.   :120.90   Max.   :208.1   Max.   :72.30  
#>    carheight       curbweight    enginetype        cylindernumber    
#>  Min.   :47.80   Min.   :1488   Length:181         Length:181        
#>  1st Qu.:52.00   1st Qu.:2122   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Median :53.70   Median :2410   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   :53.58   Mean   :2521                                        
#>  3rd Qu.:55.50   3rd Qu.:2910                                        
#>  Max.   :59.80   Max.   :4066                                        
#>    enginesize     fuelsystem          boreratio         stroke    
#>  Min.   : 61.0   Length:181         Min.   :2.540   Min.   :2.07  
#>  1st Qu.: 98.0   Class :character   1st Qu.:3.150   1st Qu.:3.08  
#>  Median :120.0   Mode  :character   Median :3.310   Median :3.23  
#>  Mean   :127.1                      Mean   :3.325   Mean   :3.23  
#>  3rd Qu.:141.0                      3rd Qu.:3.590   3rd Qu.:3.40  
#>  Max.   :326.0                      Max.   :3.940   Max.   :4.17  
#>  compressionratio   horsepower       peakrpm        citympg

#>  1st Qu.: 8.500   1st Qu.: 70.0   1st Qu.:4800   1st Qu.:19.00  
#>  Median : 9.000   Median : 95.0   Median :5200   Median :24.00

#>  3rd Qu.: 9.400   3rd Qu.:116.0   3rd Qu.:5500   3rd Qu.:30.00  
#>  Max.   :11.500   Max.   :288.0   Max.   :6600   Max.   :49.00  
#>    highwaympg        price      
#>  Min.   :16.00   Min.   : 5118  
#>  1st Qu.:25.00   1st Qu.: 7609  
#>  Median :30.00   Median : 9980  
#>  Mean   :30.48   Mean   :12999  
#>  3rd Qu.:34.00   3rd Qu.:16430  
#>  Max.   :54.00   Max.   :45400

str(df)

#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':    181 obs. of  22 variables:
#>  $ aspiration      : chr  "std" "std" "std" "std" ...
#>  $ doornumber      : chr  "two" "two" "two" "four" ...
#>  $ carbody         : chr  "convertible" "convertible" "hatchback" "sedan" ...
#>  $ drivewheel      : chr  "rwd" "rwd" "rwd" "fwd" ...
#>  $ enginelocation  : chr  "front" "front" "front" "front" ...
#>  $ wheelbase       : num  88.6 88.6 94.5 99.8 99.4 ...
#>  $ carlength       : num  169 169 171 177 177 ...
#>  $ carwidth        : num  64.1 64.1 65.5 66.2 66.4 66.3 71.4 71.4 71.4 67.9 ...
#>  $ carheight       : num  48.8 48.8 52.4 54.3 54.3 53.1 55.7 55.7 55.9 52 ...
#>  $ curbweight      : num  2548 2548 2823 2337 2824 ...
#>  $ enginetype      : chr  "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" ...
#>  $ cylindernumber  : chr  "four" "four" "six" "four" ...
#>  $ enginesize      : num  130 130 152 109 136 136 136 136 131 131 ...
#>  $ fuelsystem      : chr  "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" ...
#>  $ boreratio       : num  3.47 3.47 2.68 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.13 3.13 ...
#>  $ stroke          : num  2.68 2.68 3.47 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 ...
#>  $ compressionratio: num  9 9 9 10 8 8.5 8.5 8.5 8.3 7 ...
#>  $ horsepower      : num  111 111 154 102 115 110 110 110 140 160 ...
#>  $ peakrpm         : num  5000 5000 5000 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 ...
#>  $ citympg         : num  21 21 19 24 18 19 19 19 17 16 ...
#>  $ highwaympg      : num  27 27 26 30 22 25 25 25 20 22 ...
#>  $ price           : num  13495 16500 16500 13950 17450 ...


Numbers are defined as num and strings als chr.
##Linear regression

LG <- lm(price ~., data = df)
summary(LG)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


If the coefficient estimate is negative that means that if the value of the variable increases the price of the car decreases. If the coefficient is positive the price increases if the variable is increased.
The p-value indicates the significance of the variable if the p-value is very small e.g. enginetypeohcv< 0.001 that means that the variable is highly statically significant. The smaller the p-value the higher the statistical significance.
##Linear regression 2 Regressor is enginelocationrear
The datatype is a string. It can have either the value front or rear. The coefficient estimate is positive that means that cars having a rear engine location tend to have higher prices than cars that have a front engine. The p-value is less than 0.05 therefore indicating that it is statisically significant
##Add variable

library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attache Paket: 'dplyr'


#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

mut_df <- df %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE)
model <- lm(price ~ ., data = mut_df)
summary(model)

#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617

#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545

#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***

#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .

#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> seat_heatingTRUE             NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

The output for some reason shows NA which I dont understand. I would expect the p-value to be 0 resulting to the seat heating having an extremely low significance on the price. Which makes sense when you consider that all cars in the dataframe use it.

title: Probability Theory
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.


This is a .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

1 Assingment 1

T_scope_on_time<-0.2
T_scope_not_time<-0.8
T_on_time<-0.6
T_not_time<-0.4
P_scope<-0.3
P_no_scope<-0.7

P_T_S<-P_scope*T_scope_on_time
P_T_nS<-P_no_scope*T_on_time
P_nT_S<-P_scope*T_scope_not_time
P_nT_nS<-P_no_scope*T_not_time

P_T_S

#> [1] 0.06

P_T_nS

#> [1] 0.42

P_nT_S

#> [1] 0.24

P_nT_nS

#> [1] 0.28

sum_P<-P_T_S+P_T_nS+P_nT_S+P_nT_nS

sum_P

#> [1] 1




2 Assingment 2
What is the percentage of customers using all three devices?
0.5%
What is the percentage of customers using at least two devices?
19.4%
What is the percentage of customers using only one device?
80.1%


3 Assingment 3

P_A<-0.04
P_nA<-1-P_A
P_BA<-0.97
P_BnA<-0.01

P_B<-P_BA*P_A+P_BnA*P_nA
P_AB<-(P_BA*P_A)/P_B
P_nAB<-(P_BnA*P_nA)/P_B

print(P_AB)

#> [1] 0.8016529

print(P_nAB)

#> [1] 0.1983471


These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 20% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80% that the product is faulty.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
#Assingment

random_vars <- readRDS("data/random_vars.rds")

View(random_vars)

mean_var1 <- mean(random_vars$age)
variance_var1 <- var(random_vars$age)
std_var1 <- sd(random_vars$age)

mean_var2 <- mean(random_vars$income)
variance_var2 <- var(random_vars$income)
std_var2 <- sd(random_vars$income)

##
mean_var1

#> [1] 33.471

variance_var1

#> [1] 340.6078

std_var1

#> [1] 18.45556

mean_var2

#> [1] 3510.731

variance_var2

#> [1] 8625646

std_var2

#> [1] 2936.945

##

covariance <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)
correlation <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)

##
covariance

#> [1] 29700.15

correlation

#> [1] 0.5479432

##

df_sub18 <- subset(random_vars, age >= 18)
df_sub18_65 <- subset(random_vars, age >= 18 & age <= 65)
df_sub65 <- subset(random_vars, age <= 65)

mean_df_sub18 <- mean(df_sub18$income)
mean_df_sub18_65 <- mean(df_sub18_65$income)
mean_df_sub65 <- mean(df_sub65$income)

mean_df_sub18

#> [1] 4464.027

mean_df_sub18_65

#> [1] 4691.378

mean_df_sub65

#> [1] 3625.972

title: Causality
text:
##Assignment

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attache Paket: 'dplyr'


#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

month <- c(1:12)
ice_cream_consumption <- c(50, 48, 40, 35, 30, 25, 15, 12, 25, 35, 48, 55)
drownings <- c(10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 40, 55, 60, 45, 35, 22, 15)

df1 <- data.frame(month, ice_cream_consumption)
df2 <- data.frame(month, drownings)


ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = df1, aes(x = month, y = ice_cream_consumption, color = "Ice Cream Consumption"), linetype = "solid") +
  geom_line(data = df2, aes(x = month, y = drownings, color = "Number of Drownings"), linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Ice Cream Consumption", sec.axis = sec_axis(~., name = "Number of Drownings")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Ice Cream Consumption" = "blue", "Number of Drownings" = "red")) +
  labs(x = "Month") +
  ggtitle("Two Line Plots: Ice Cream and Drowning")

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)

#> Warning: Paket 'tidyverse' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt


#> Warning: Paket 'tidyr' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt


#> Warning: Paket 'readr' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt


#> Warning: Paket 'purrr' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt


#> Warning: Paket 'forcats' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt


#> Warning: Paket 'lubridate' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt


#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

# Load the data
abtest_data <- readRDS("C:\\Users\\Deniz\\Documents\\GitHub\\Causal_Data_Science_Data\\abtest_online.rds")

# Explore the data
head(abtest_data)



  


summary(abtest_data)

#>       ip             chatbot        previous_visit   mobile_device  
#>  Length:1000        Mode :logical   Min.   : 0.000   Mode :logical  
#>  Class :character   FALSE:496       1st Qu.: 1.000   FALSE:683      
#>  Mode  :character   TRUE :504       Median : 1.000   TRUE :317      
#>                                     Mean   : 2.021                  
#>                                     3rd Qu.: 3.000                  
#>                                     Max.   :13.000                  
#>     purchase     purchase_amount
#>  Min.   :0.000   Min.   : 0.00  
#>  1st Qu.:0.000   1st Qu.: 0.00  
#>  Median :0.000   Median : 0.00  
#>  Mean   :0.381   Mean   :13.14  
#>  3rd Qu.:1.000   3rd Qu.:27.44  
#>  Max.   :1.000   Max.   :81.35

# Check covariate balance across groups
covariate_balance_plot <- ggplot(abtest_data, aes(x = chatbot, y = mobile_device, color = chatbot)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Covariate Balance Check",
       x = "Chatbot",
       y = "Mobile Device") +
  theme_minimal()

# Display covariate balance plot
print(covariate_balance_plot)







# Run a regression to find the effect of chatbot on sales (purchase_amount)
regression_model <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, data = abtest_data)
summary(regression_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.414 -14.428  -8.435  12.559  64.584 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)        15.2840     1.1227  13.614  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE        -6.8488     1.1792  -5.808 8.49e-09 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.8562     1.2642  -0.677  0.49841    
#> previous_visit      0.7792     0.2869   2.716  0.00673 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03954 
#> F-statistic: 14.71 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 2.228e-09

# Find subgroup-specific effects by including an interaction term
interaction_model <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device + previous_visit, data = abtest_data)
summary(interaction_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.403 -14.450  -8.445  12.549  64.562 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                   15.27384    1.19130  12.821  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                   -6.82837    1.42580  -4.789 1.93e-06 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE             -0.82375    1.79309  -0.459  0.64605    
#> previous_visit                 0.77914    0.28711   2.714  0.00677 ** 
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE -0.06455    2.52907  -0.026  0.97964    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 995 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03858 
#> F-statistic: 11.02 on 4 and 995 DF,  p-value: 9.485e-09

# Compute CATE for mobile users
mobile_users_effect <- coef(interaction_model)["chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE"]

# Run a logistic regression for binary outcome (purchase)
logistic_model <- glm(purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
                      family = binomial(link = 'logit'), data = abtest_data)
summary(logistic_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     family = binomial(link = "logit"), data = abtest_data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)       -0.22185    0.12347  -1.797  0.07237 .  
#> chatbotTRUE       -0.96894    0.13564  -7.144 9.09e-13 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE -0.07119    0.14530  -0.490  0.62417    
#> previous_visit     0.10606    0.03262   3.252  0.00115 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1262.2  on 996  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1270.2
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4



chatbotTRUE: The estimated change in purchase_amount when chatbot is TRUE compared to when it is FALSE. A negative coefficient suggests that the presence of a chatbot is associated with a decrease in purchase_amount.
The CATE for mobile users (chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE)is -0.06455 in the model. However, this coefficient is not statistically significant, indicating that there is no significant distinction in the impact of the chatbot on sales (purchase_amount) between mobile and non-mobile users.
Coefficient for chatbotTRUE in the logistic regression model is -0.96894. Therefore:

A negative coefficient suggests that the presence of the chatbot is associated with a decrease in the log-odds of making a purchase compared to when the chatbot is not present. It implies that customers exposed to the chatbot are less likely to make a purchase (purchase = 1) compared to those not exposed, according to the model.
